The large scale of Inner Asian migrations into China in the early Tang—potentially entailing more than one million persons—had a significant impact on the ethnic composition of the empire. Some scholars estimate that in 639 non-Han migrants made up 6 to 7 percent of the total population of the empire and 12 to 14 percent of the population of North China. Calculations of the readily identifiable non-Han population at various periods in the Tang range from 10 to 19 percent
